handDesc.handNote: description of letters, possibly including letter-heights

history.provenance: Modern location(s) (if different from repository, above)

div.p:
ratu ṅarana,
sri maḥharaja ratu
haji ri pakvan· sya saṁ ratu
devata pun·, masa sya
ṅrətakən· bumi ṅaha
lipukən· na bvan·na
ñuruḥ saṁ disi suk·laja
ti ṅaR̥buḥkən· Ikaṁ ka
yu sipadakaḥ, ṅalaAn·
na Udubasu, mipati
kən·n ikaṁ kala

app.note: The sign read as pu by HD is quite faded, but resembles much more closely the ṅa in l. 8. Moreover, the vocalization u below the sign to the left is perfectly clear, so it is very hard to suppose the presence of another such vocalization which would be totally invisible right next to it.
At the transition between these lines, one might restore baduga or prəbu.
in HD’s eye-copy, the consonant j is a clear, but the estampages do not allow to confirm this reading. But comparison with Batutulis, line 3, strongly suggests that indeed one needs to restore haji.
HD’s drawing suggests a difference between ə and ö which is not actually there on the stone.
See the preceding note. HD note that between ṅaha and lipukən consist a gap, which in our opinion this is unbreak word and in there is no gap in the stone.
Eventhough the verb ñuruḥ doesn't occured in the MdS, we found the nominalisation form pañuruhan in OSd, as it has been recorded in SSK.6.
There indeed seems to be some element below the akṣara di (cf. HD’s dv), but in our opinion it is most likely to be accidental.
There is clearly a vocalisation u that has escaped HD’s attention.

div.p: […] king his name, […] Sri Maharaja King of Kings in Pakuan. He was Sang Ratu Dewata, when he made the world prosperous, pleased the earth, ordered Sang Disi Suklajati to fell the tree called (named) Sipadakah, removed Udubasu, killed Kala.

Hassan Djafar (1994) indicated with ellipsis at the beginnings and ends of all lines except line 3 that an undetermined number of akṣaras has been lost there. This, we feel, is too imprecise. In fact it seems that a rather small number of akṣaras is lost, because we can read unintterrupted words at the transitions between lines 5–6, 7–8, 8–9 and 10–11. This means that not more than 1 akṣara is lost at the right ends of lines 1, 2, 3 and 6. It is not possible to estimate with precision the number of akṣaras that might have been lost at the openings of lines 1 and 2. Variant readings of Hasan Djafar’s edition are indicated with HD.
bibliography of previous editions, discussion, etc.
